conclusion: The working principle of a certain type of mass spectrometer is shown in Figure (1). M and N are two vertically placed metal plates with a voltage U between them. Plate Q is the recording plate, and interface P divides the region between N and Q into two parts, I and II, each with a width of d. The planes of M, N, P, and Q are parallel to each other. a and b are two small, directly opposed holes on M and N, respectively. Taking the line passing through a and b as the z-axis, with the right direction as positive, and the intersection point o of the z-axis and plate Q as the origin, a Cartesian coordinate system Oxyz is established. The positive x-axis is parallel to plate Q and points horizontally inward, and the positive y-axis is vertically upward. Region I is filled with a uniform magnetic field along the positive x-axis with magnetic field strength B, and region II is filled with a uniform electric field along the positive x-axis with electric field strength E. A particle with mass m and charge +q drifts into the electric field from hole a (initial velocity considered zero), passes through hole b, enters the magnetic field, passes through point c on plane P (not drawn in the figure), and then enters the electric field before finally hitting the recording plate Q. The gravity of the particle is negligible.
Determine the radius R of the circular path of the particle in the magnetic field.

Figure (1) shows metal plates M and N with a voltage U between them, and plate Q as the recording plate. Interface P divides the region between N and Q into two parts, I and II, each with a width of d. The planes of M, N, P, and Q are parallel to each other. a and b are two small, directly opposed holes on M and N, respectively. The line passing through a and b is the z-axis, with the right direction as positive, and the intersection point o of the z-axis and plate Q is the origin. A Cartesian coordinate system Oxyz is established with the positive x-axis parallel to plate Q and pointing horizontally inward, and the positive y-axis vertically upward. Region I is filled with a uniform magnetic field along the positive x-axis with magnetic field strength B, and region II is filled with a uniform electric field along the positive x-axis with electric field strength E.

premise: The particle starts from rest in the electric field between plates M and N. The electric field E_1 between the plates is given by E_1 = U/d. The force on the particle is F = qE_1.
conclusion: The acceleration a of the particle is a = F/m = qE_1/m = qU/md.

premise: Using the kinematic equation v^2 = u^2 + 2as, where u = 0 (initial velocity), s = d, and a = qU/md.

conclusion: The velocity v when the particle exits hole b is v = sqrt(2qU/m).

premise: The particle enters the magnetic field with velocity v perpendicular to the magnetic field B. The magnetic force provides the centripetal force for circular motion: qvB = mv^2/R.
From Step 1, v = sqrt(2qU/m). Substitute v into the equation for R: R = mv/(qB).
